The <em>nike</em> dunk high is both fashion and practical that it is time <em>to</em> own one pair.", "explanation": null, "document": "Dec 19, 2011\nWhat an unlikely trio. Or not?\nOn December 15th, Christopher Hitchens, the contrarian polemicist, got to wherever it is that we all get to go - first.\nHitchen's wasn't everyone's cup of tea but he might have appealed, at least weakly, at some level.\nOn the 17th, Vaclav Havel of the Velvet Revolution, playwright turned activist and the architect of the Czech republic followed.\nHavel appears to have been much revered, though seems less instantly recognizable. Perhaps his ego was better managed as popularity waned, after his modern-day-democratic miracle. Celebrity, however, is relative and context dependent. It's unlikely that Hitchens is being mourned in Prague, in quite the same way as Havel.\nAnd then, this morning, we learned that Kim Jong Il, North Korea's secretive, Communist dictator relic had also joined the club. Curiously, this was reported some two days after the fact. As is clear with everything about that murky place, the balance betwixt celebration and mourning is not easily calibrated.\nI suspect that Hitchens and Havel may have shared sensibilities. Though these were expressed in vastly different forms, their tendencies appear to have died right alongside them.\u00a0 As for Kim Jong Il, his assertion that \"great ideology creates great times\" remains inexplicable, outside of the totalitarian bubble he presided over in a reincarnation of his own father, Kim Il-Sung. Now, his legend appears set to live on in Kim Jong-un, his equally unpredictable great successor. Hitchens had earlier imagined such a \"necrocratic trinity\".\nAs different as they were, I find it fitting to quote from Tom Rachman's brilliant debut novel The Imperfectionists. This might apply to all three:\n\"I say that ambition is absurd and yet I remain in its thrall... from my earliest childhood it dominated me. I longed for achievements, to be influential - that, in particular. To sway people. This has been my religion: the belief that I deserve attention, that they are wrong not to listen, that those who dispute me are fools. Yet, no matter what I achieve, the world lives on, impertinent indifferent.\u00a0 Here is a fact: nothing in all civilization has been as productive and ludicrous as ambition. Whatever its ills, nothing has created more. Cathedrals, sonata's, encyclopedias: love of God was not behind them, not love of life. But the love of man to be worshipped by man....\"\nThere's a queue forming at the great humidor in the sky.\nI hear they all smoked like chimneys.\nWho could ever think that God doesn't have a sense of humour?\n"}, {"score": 344.5406, "uuid": "46e54581-74aa-5fb9-80ec-3cc1ef4f922c", "index": "cw12", "trec_id": "clueweb12-0814wb-63-09461", "target_hostname": "www.expatriateliving.com", "target_uri": "http://www.expatriateliving.com/expat/index.php?option=com_myblog&show=omne-trium-perfectum.html&Itemid=349", "page_rank": 1.1700305e-09, "spam_rank": 89, "title": "&quot;omne trium perfectum?&quot;", "snippet": "<em>I</em> <em>am</em> decide <em>to</em> put into use one of The North Face Thank you for sharing it,<em>To</em> Your Succes! <em>Nike</em> brand shoes help the buyers <em>to</em> select the best pair of <em>nike</em> dunks high that they want <em>to</em> keep for themselves. I do like to look good when working out, but also like to have something thats more comfortable than anything else. I usually go for jogs in the morning, which is refreshing in the summer, but freezing in the winter. I know it's always hard to dress for exercise in the cold, because you quickly build up a sweat and get hot.\nI'd recommend some colour, just for some extra motivation. It just adds a bit of fun. A few good comfortable pairs of sweat pants are essential. I'd go for these instead of shorts, because you don't want to get too cold. But it's tougher when it gets to arms. Personally, I'd wear a tank or a t-shirt, and I'd avoid wearing a hoody on top because when you get hot, you'll have no where to put the hoody. What I do like are the off-shoulder jumper like things (yup, I don't know what they're called). They're really comfortable, and also really light, so perfect for a run.\nBut, what you really need for a good run are a decent pair of running shoes. I'd say get one expensive pair from Nike. They do really good trainers, that don't look too bad either. A good pair of running shoes are essential for a run. They support your feet really well and are also really comfortable. I have a pair of Sport Skechers and they really are perfect for a run. They are designed with the typical movements of a player on a certain position in mind, thus their choice is rather preferred than obligatory. High-tops protect by covering up to the ankle and provide extra stability for lateral movements. They are made for players in the linemen position. Low-cuts are the total opposite of high-tops, being small in height, but therefore very light. They support whoever is required or wishes to make small, quick movements on the field. With these two palettes, the new football boots 2012 shoes should be able to fill the needs of the majority of players. If not, there is still the option of mid-cut in f50 adizero prime 2012 shoes. Like football itself football shoes have gone through a lot of changes over the years. Before 1891 studs?blades or any other kind of sole were not allowed. After the 1891 changes?studs and blades became legal as long as they were made of leather and not as big as half an inch. These studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players of the time had many pairs with various stud lengths and this is probably the first time 2012 new adidas predator have evolved. The second evolution began in the mid-1950s and it is the most controversial. Football history noted that during the 1950's in Switzerland?Adidas who was Germany's boot supplier kitted the German team with the first ever screw-in-studs 2012 f50 adizero . However?Puma have counter claimed that they were supplying screw-in-studs as early as 1952. But whoever invented screw-in-studs the second evolution was the invention of the screw-in-studs boots. The first record of a pair of f50 adizero prime 2012 appears in 1526 in a list from King Henry VIII's Great Wardrobe which suggests he was not short of a few boots: \"45 velvet pairs and 1 leather pair for football\". His new 2012 adipowear predator were made by his personal shoemaker, Cornelius Johnson in 1525 at a cost of 4 shillings (about \uffe1100 in today's money). They were made of strong leather, ankle high and heavier than the normal shoe of the day\u2026 which position Henry played, we shall never know. The earliest mercurial vapor 2012 had metal tacks hammered into them to increase ground grip and stability. With the foundation of the Football Association in 1863, rules were introduced that banned any kind of projection on the soles or heels of new 2012 football shoes but in 1891 the rules were revised to allow studs, so long as they were made of leather, were rounded, did not project more than half an inch and had their fastenings driven in. Believe it or not the use of adidas football boots 2012 dates back to Henry VIII of England. Her majesty ordered a pair from the Great Wardrobe in 1526, the royal shopping list stated: \"45 velvet pairs and 1 leather pair for football\". Since then new f50 adizero 2012 evolved to be an essential part of the game and nowadays they are made with high-materials such as carbon fibre and synthetic leather. Just like football itself 2012 new adidas predator went through a lot changes over the years. Until 1891, studs, blades or any other kind of projection weren't allowed. After the 1891 revision, studs and bladders became \"legal\" as long as they were made of leather and weren't bigger than half an inch, this studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players at the time had several pairs with different length studs. I consider this as the first time 2012 new football boots evolved. The second evolution came in the mid-1950s and it is also the most controversial. History says that during the 1954 in Switzerland, Adidas who was Germany's football boot supplier kitted the Germans with the first screw-in-studs messi 2012 boots ever seen. But recently Puma claimed that they were supplying screw in stud as early as 1952. Despite who invented screw in studs the point here is the that the second evolution was the invention of the screw in studs. Despite the screw-in debate another revolution was going on at roughly the same time in history. Between 1950 and 1960 new 2012 football shoes design took a huge step forward and boots really started to make an impact on the game. While in Northern Europe adidas football boots 2012 still had the ankle protection, main reason they are called \"boots\", South Americans created a more flexible and lighter boot without the ankle protection, a boot designed to increase control, improve kicking power and make players move faster and change direction quicker. As the years passed technological advancements allowed manufacturers to produce lighter boots in a variety of colours and studs configurations. Highlights to the Puma King worn players like Pel? at the 1970 World Cup and to one of the best selling football boot to date, the Adidas Copa Mundial. We can't talk about the evolution of 2012 nike tiempo legend fg cleats without mentioning Craig Johnston, creator of the Adidas Predator. Johnston revolutionised the football boot market by creating a boot that provided more traction between ball and boot, and boot and the ground, the Adidas Predator was born. With greater contact areas, a series of power and swerve zones allowing players to create better swerves and more powerful strikes when hitting the so called \"sweet spots\". No wonder the Adidas Predator series are still in production these days. Johnston's creation was just the tip of the iceberg of what was coming. Polymer extrusion technologies and other materials allowed the creating of more flexible soles; studs were replaced by blades which gave players a more stable base. The shape of your feet, your running style and the position you play usually matter when buying 2012 new football boots . Choose a pair that is lighter in weight, stronger in the make and one that suits your most common playing surface. Buying boots for every playing condition is not worth your money unless you are a frequent player. The uppers of a football boot are generally made out of leather, synthetic material or a combination. Leather is more durable and takes the shape of your foot easily. It is known to be comfortable but has the tendency to stretch in wet conditions. The more expensive leather types used in new 2012 football shoes is Kangaroo leather. If you are opting for a synthetic upper, make sure it is of good quality synthetic that does not rip, tear, peel off and damage under strain. Synthetic material can withstand all kinds of weather conditions and are lightweight. Hidden lacing system and side lacing are used in newer boots for more contact area on the shoe and for greater ball control. Side lacing helps reduce pressure on the nerves of your foot. A durable pair of mercurial vapor 2012 which are comfortable can be more practical than a highly expensive pair with features that are not essential. After the 1891 changes?studs and blades became legal as long as they were made of leather and not as big as half an inch. These studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players of the time had many pairs with various stud lengths and this is probably the first time 2012 new adidas predator have evolved. After the 1891 changes?studs and blades became legal as long as they were made of leather and not as big as half an inch. These studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players of the time had many pairs with various stud lengths and this is probably the first time 2012 new adidas predator have evolved. The second evolution began in the mid-1950s and it is the most controversial. After the 1891 changes?studs and blades became legal as long as they were made of leather and not as big as half an inch. These studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players of the time had many pairs with various stud lengths and this is probably the first time 2012 new adidas predator have evolved. After the 1891 changes?studs and blades became legal as long as they were made of leather and not as big as half an inch. After the 1891 changes?studs and blades became legal as long as they were made of leather and not as big as half an inch. These studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players of the time had many pairs with various stud lengths and this is probably the first time 2012 new adidas predator have evolved. The second evolution began in the mid-1950s and it is the most controversial. However?Puma have counter claimed that they were supplying screw-in-studs as early as 1952. But whoever invented screw-in-studs the second evolution was the invention of the screw-in-studs boots. After the 1891 changes?studs and blades became legal as long as they were made of leather and not as big as half an inch. These studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players of the time had many pairs with various stud lengths and this is probably the first time 2012 new adidas predator have evolved. The second evolution began in the mid-1950s and it is the most controversial. However?Puma have counter claimed that they were supplying screw-in-studs as early as 1952. But whoever invented screw-in-studs the second evolution was the invention of the screw-in-studs boots. After the 1891 changes?studs and blades became legal as long as they were made of leather and not as big as half an inch. These studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players of the time had many pairs with various stud lengths and this is probably the first time 2012 new adidas predator have evolved. The second evolution began in the mid-1950s and it is the most controversial. However?Puma have counter claimed that they were supplying screw-in-studs as early as 1952. But whoever invented screw-in-studs the second evolution was the invention of the screw-in-studs boots. Like football itself football shoes have gone through a lot of changes over the years. Before 1891 studs?blades or any other kind of sole were not allowed. After the 1891 changes?studs and blades became legal as long as they were made of leather and not as big as half an inch. These studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players of the time had many pairs with various stud lengths and this is probably the first time 2012 new adidas predator have evolved. The second evolution began in the mid-1950s and it is the most controversial. Football history noted that during the 1950's in Switzerland?Adidas who was Germany's boot supplier kitted the German team with the first ever screw-in-studs 2012 f50 adizero . However?Puma have counter claimed that they were supplying screw-in-studs as early as 1952. But whoever invented screw-in-studs the second evolution was the invention of the screw-in-studs boots. His new 2012 adipowear predator were made by his personal shoemaker, Cornelius Johnson in 1525 at a cost of 4 shillings (about \uffe1100 in today's money). With the foundation of the Football Association in 1863, rules were introduced that banned any kind of projection on the soles or heels of new 2012 football shoes but in 1891 the rules were revised to allow studs, so long as they were made of leather, were rounded, did not project more than half an inch and had their fastenings driven in. Like football itself football shoes have gone through a lot of changes over the years. Before 1891 studs?blades or any other kind of sole were not allowed. After the 1891 changes?studs and blades became legal as long as they were made of leather and not as big as half an inch. These studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players of the time had many pairs with various stud lengths and this is probably the first time 2012 new adidas predator have evolved. The second evolution began in the mid-1950s and it is the most controversial. Football history noted that during the 1950's in Switzerland?Adidas who was Germany's boot supplier kitted the German team with the first ever screw-in-studs 2012 f50 adizero . However?Puma have counter claimed that they were supplying screw-in-studs as early as 1952. But whoever invented screw-in-studs the second evolution was the invention of the screw-in-studs boots. The first record of a pair of f50 adizero prime 2012 appears in 1526 in a list from King Henry VIII's Great Wardrobe which suggests he was not short of a few boots: \"45 velvet pairs and 1 leather pair for football\". His new 2012 adipowear predator were made by his personal shoemaker, Cornelius Johnson in 1525 at a cost of 4 shillings (about \uffe1100 in today's money). They were made of strong leather, ankle high and heavier than the normal shoe of the day\u2026 which position Henry played, we shall never know. The earliest mercurial vapor 2012 had metal tacks hammered into them to increase ground grip and stability. With the foundation of the Football Association in 1863, rules were introduced that banned any kind of projection on the soles or heels of new 2012 football shoes but in 1891 the rules were revised to allow studs, so long as they were made of leather, were rounded, did not project more than half an inch and had their fastenings driven in. But recently Puma claimed that they were supplying screw in stud as early as 1952. Like football itself football shoes have gone through a lot of changes over the years. Before 1891 studs?blades or any other kind of sole were not allowed. After the 1891 changes?studs and blades became legal as long as they were made of leather and not as big as half an inch. These studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players of the time had many pairs with various stud lengths and this is probably the first time 2012 new adidas predator have evolved. The second evolution began in the mid-1950s and it is the most controversial. Football history noted that during the 1950's in Switzerland?Adidas who was Germany's boot supplier kitted the German team with the first ever screw-in-studs 2012 f50 adizero . However?Puma have counter claimed that they were supplying screw-in-studs as early as 1952. But whoever invented screw-in-studs the second evolution was the invention of the screw-in-studs boots. The first record of a pair of f50 adizero prime 2012 appears in 1526 in a list from King Henry VIII's Great Wardrobe which suggests he was not short of a few boots: \"45 velvet pairs and 1 leather pair for football\". His new 2012 adipowear predator were made by his personal shoemaker, Cornelius Johnson in 1525 at a cost of 4 shillings (about \uffe1100 in today's money). They were made of strong leather, ankle high and heavier than the normal shoe of the day\u2026 which position Henry played, we shall never know. The earliest mercurial vapor 2012 had metal tacks hammered into them to increase ground grip and stability. With the foundation of the Football Association in 1863, rules were introduced that banned any kind of projection on the soles or heels of new 2012 football shoes but in 1891 the rules were revised to allow studs, so long as they were made of leather, were rounded, did not project more than half an inch and had their fastenings driven in. But recently Puma claimed that they were supplying screw in stud as early as 1952. Like football itself football shoes have gone through a lot of changes over the years. Before 1891 studs?blades or any other kind of sole were not allowed. After the 1891 changes?studs and blades became legal as long as they were made of leather and not as big as half an inch. These studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players of the time had many pairs with various stud lengths and this is probably the first time 2012 new adidas predator have evolved. The second evolution began in the mid-1950s and it is the most controversial. Football history noted that during the 1950's in Switzerland?Adidas who was Germany's boot supplier kitted the German team with the first ever screw-in-studs 2012 f50 adizero . However?Puma have counter claimed that they were supplying screw-in-studs as early as 1952. But whoever invented screw-in-studs the second evolution was the invention of the screw-in-studs boots. The first record of a pair of f50 adizero prime 2012 appears in 1526 in a list from King Henry VIII's Great Wardrobe which suggests he was not short of a few boots: \"45 velvet pairs and 1 leather pair for football\". His new 2012 adipowear predator were made by his personal shoemaker, Cornelius Johnson in 1525 at a cost of 4 shillings (about \uffe1100 in today's money). They were made of strong leather, ankle high and heavier than the normal shoe of the day\u2026 which position Henry played, we shall never know. The earliest mercurial vapor 2012 had metal tacks hammered into them to increase ground grip and stability. With the foundation of the Football Association in 1863, rules were introduced that banned any kind of projection on the soles or heels of new 2012 football shoes but in 1891 the rules were revised to allow studs, so long as they were made of leather, were rounded, did not project more than half an inch and had their fastenings driven in. I consider this as the first time 2012 new football boots evolved. The second evolution came in the mid-1950s and it is also the most controversial. History says that during the 1954 in Switzerland, Adidas who was Germany's football boot supplier kitted the Germans with the first screw-in-studs messi 2012 boots ever seen. But recently Puma claimed that they were supplying screw in stud as early as 1952. Despite who invented screw in studs the point here is the that the second evolution was the invention of the screw in studs. Like football itself football shoes have gone through a lot of changes over the years. Before 1891 studs?blades or any other kind of sole were not allowed. After the 1891 changes?studs and blades became legal as long as they were made of leather and not as big as half an inch. These studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players of the time had many pairs with various stud lengths and this is probably the first time 2012 new adidas predator have evolved. The second evolution began in the mid-1950s and it is the most controversial. Football history noted that during the 1950's in Switzerland?Adidas who was Germany's boot supplier kitted the German team with the first ever screw-in-studs 2012 f50 adizero . However?Puma have counter claimed that they were supplying screw-in-studs as early as 1952. But whoever invented screw-in-studs the second evolution was the invention of the screw-in-studs boots. The first record of a pair of f50 adizero prime 2012 appears in 1526 in a list from King Henry VIII's Great Wardrobe which suggests he was not short of a few boots: \"45 velvet pairs and 1 leather pair for football\". His new 2012 adipowear predator were made by his personal shoemaker, Cornelius Johnson in 1525 at a cost of 4 shillings (about \uffe1100 in today's money). They were made of strong leather, ankle high and heavier than the normal shoe of the day\u2026 which position Henry played, we shall never know. The earliest mercurial vapor 2012 had metal tacks hammered into them to increase ground grip and stability. With the foundation of the Football Association in 1863, rules were introduced that banned any kind of projection on the soles or heels of new 2012 football shoes but in 1891 the rules were revised to allow studs, so long as they were made of leather, were rounded, did not project more than half an inch and had their fastenings driven in. Just like football itself 2012 new adidas predator went through a lot changes over the years. Until 1891, studs, blades or any other kind of projection weren't allowed. After the 1891 revision, studs and bladders became \"legal\" as long as they were made of leather and weren't bigger than half an inch, this studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players at the time had several pairs with different length studs. I consider this as the first time 2012 new football boots evolved. The second evolution came in the mid-1950s and it is also the most controversial. History says that during the 1954 in Switzerland, Adidas who was Germany's football boot supplier kitted the Germans with the first screw-in-studs messi 2012 boots ever seen. But recently Puma claimed that they were supplying screw in stud as early as 1952. Despite who invented screw in studs the point here is the that the second evolution was the invention of the screw in studs. Despite the screw-in debate another revolution was going on at roughly the same time in history. Between 1950 and 1960 new 2012 football shoes design took a huge step forward and boots really started to make an impact on the game. While in Northern Europe adidas football boots 2012 still had the ankle protection, main reason they are called \"boots\", South Americans created a more flexible and lighter boot without the ankle protection, a boot designed to increase control, improve kicking power and make players move faster and change direction quicker. Like football itself football shoes have gone through a lot of changes over the years. Before 1891 studs?blades or any other kind of sole were not allowed. After the 1891 changes?studs and blades became legal as long as they were made of leather and not as big as half an inch. These studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players of the time had many pairs with various stud lengths and this is probably the first time 2012 new adidas predator have evolved. The second evolution began in the mid-1950s and it is the most controversial. Football history noted that during the 1950's in Switzerland?Adidas who was Germany's boot supplier kitted the German team with the first ever screw-in-studs 2012 f50 adizero . However?Puma have counter claimed that they were supplying screw-in-studs as early as 1952. But whoever invented screw-in-studs the second evolution was the invention of the screw-in-studs boots. I consider this as the first time 2012 new football boots evolved. The second evolution came in the mid-1950s and it is also the most controversial. Like football itself football shoes have gone through a lot of changes over the years. Before 1891 studs?blades or any other kind of sole were not allowed. After the 1891 changes?studs and blades became legal as long as they were made of leather and not as big as half an inch. These studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players of the time had many pairs with various stud lengths and this is probably the first time 2012 new adidas predator have evolved. The second evolution began in the mid-1950s and it is the most controversial. Football history noted that during the 1950's in Switzerland?Adidas who was Germany's boot supplier kitted the German team with the first ever screw-in-studs 2012 f50 adizero . However?Puma have counter claimed that they were supplying screw-in-studs as early as 1952. But whoever invented screw-in-studs the second evolution was the invention of the screw-in-studs boots. The first record of a pair of f50 adizero prime 2012 appears in 1526 in a list from King Henry VIII's Great Wardrobe which suggests he was not short of a few boots: \"45 velvet pairs and 1 leather pair for football\". His new 2012 adipowear predator were made by his personal shoemaker, Cornelius Johnson in 1525 at a cost of 4 shillings (about \uffe1100 in today's money). They were made of strong leather, ankle high and heavier than the normal shoe of the day\u2026 which position Henry played, we shall never know. The earliest mercurial vapor 2012 had metal tacks hammered into them to increase ground grip and stability. With the foundation of the Football Association in 1863, rules were introduced that banned any kind of projection on the soles or heels of new 2012 football shoes but in 1891 the rules were revised to allow studs, so long as they were made of leather, were rounded, did not project more than half an inch and had their fastenings driven in. Believe it or not the use of adidas football boots 2012 dates back to Henry VIII of England. Her majesty ordered a pair from the Great Wardrobe in 1526, the royal shopping list stated: \"45 velvet pairs and 1 leather pair for football\". Just like football itself 2012 new adidas predator went through a lot changes over the years. Until 1891, studs, blades or any other kind of projection weren't allowed. After the 1891 revision, studs and bladders became \"legal\" as long as they were made of leather and weren't bigger than half an inch, this studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players at the time had several pairs with different length studs. I consider this as the first time 2012 new football boots evolved. The second evolution came in the mid-1950s and it is also the most controversial. History says that during the 1954 in Switzerland, Adidas who was Germany's football boot supplier kitted the Germans with the first screw-in-studs messi 2012 boots ever seen. But recently Puma claimed that they were supplying screw in stud as early as 1952. Despite who invented screw in studs the point here is the that the second evolution was the invention of the screw in studs. Despite the screw-in debate another revolution was going on at roughly the same time in history. Between 1950 and 1960 new 2012 football shoes design took a huge step forward and boots really started to make an impact on the game. While in Northern Europe adidas football boots 2012 still had the ankle protection, main reason they are called \"boots\", South Americans created a more flexible and lighter boot without the ankle protection, a boot designed to increase control, improve kicking power and make players move faster and change direction quicker. Johnston revolutionised the football boot market by creating a boot that provided more traction between ball and boot, and boot and the ground, the Adidas Predator was born. With greater contact areas, a series of power and swerve zones allowing players to create better swerves and more powerful strikes when hitting the so called \"sweet spots\". No wonder the Adidas Predator series are still in production these days. Johnston's creation was just the tip of the iceberg of what was coming. Like football itself football shoes have gone through a lot of changes over the years. Before 1891 studs?blades or any other kind of sole were not allowed. After the 1891 changes?studs and blades became legal as long as they were made of leather and not as big as half an inch. These studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players of the time had many pairs with various stud lengths and this is probably the first time 2012 new adidas predator have evolved. The second evolution began in the mid-1950s and it is the most controversial. Football history noted that during the 1950's in Switzerland?Adidas who was Germany's boot supplier kitted the German team with the first ever screw-in-studs 2012 f50 adizero . However?Puma have counter claimed that they were supplying screw-in-studs as early as 1952. But whoever invented screw-in-studs the second evolution was the invention of the screw-in-studs boots. The first record of a pair of f50 adizero prime 2012 appears in 1526 in a list from King Henry VIII's Great Wardrobe which suggests he was not short of a few boots: \"45 velvet pairs and 1 leather pair for football\". His new 2012 adipowear predator were made by his personal shoemaker, Cornelius Johnson in 1525 at a cost of 4 shillings (about \uffe1100 in today's money). They were made of strong leather, ankle high and heavier than the normal shoe of the day\u2026 which position Henry played, we shall never know. The earliest mercurial vapor 2012 had metal tacks hammered into them to increase ground grip and stability. With the foundation of the Football Association in 1863, rules were introduced that banned any kind of projection on the soles or heels of new 2012 football shoes but in 1891 the rules were revised to allow studs, so long as they were made of leather, were rounded, did not project more than half an inch and had their fastenings driven in. Believe it or not the use of adidas football boots 2012 dates back to Henry VIII of England. Her majesty ordered a pair from the Great Wardrobe in 1526, the royal shopping list stated: \"45 velvet pairs and 1 leather pair for football\". Just like football itself 2012 new adidas predator went through a lot changes over the years. Until 1891, studs, blades or any other kind of projection weren't allowed. After the 1891 revision, studs and bladders became \"legal\" as long as they were made of leather and weren't bigger than half an inch, this studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players at the time had several pairs with different length studs. I consider this as the first time 2012 new football boots evolved. The second evolution came in the mid-1950s and it is also the most controversial. History says that during the 1954 in Switzerland, Adidas who was Germany's football boot supplier kitted the Germans with the first screw-in-studs messi 2012 boots ever seen. But recently Puma claimed that they were supplying screw in stud as early as 1952. Despite who invented screw in studs the point here is the that the second evolution was the invention of the screw in studs. Despite the screw-in debate another revolution was going on at roughly the same time in history. Between 1950 and 1960 new 2012 football shoes design took a huge step forward and boots really started to make an impact on the game. While in Northern Europe adidas football boots 2012 still had the ankle protection, main reason they are called \"boots\", South Americans created a more flexible and lighter boot without the ankle protection, a boot designed to increase control, improve kicking power and make players move faster and change direction quicker. Johnston revolutionised the football boot market by creating a boot that provided more traction between ball and boot, and boot and the ground, the Adidas Predator was born. With greater contact areas, a series of power and swerve zones allowing players to create better swerves and more powerful strikes when hitting the so called \"sweet spots\". No wonder the Adidas Predator series are still in production these days. Johnston's creation was just the tip of the iceberg of what was coming. After the 1891 changes?studs and blades became legal as long as they were made of leather and not as big as half an inch. These studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players of the time had many pairs with various stud lengths and this is probably the first time 2012 new adidas predator have evolved. The second evolution began in the mid-1950s and it is the most controversial. However?Puma have counter claimed that they were supplying screw-in-studs as early as 1952. But whoever invented screw-in-studs the second evolution was the invention of the screw-in-studs boots. After the 1891 changes?studs and blades became legal as long as they were made of leather and not as big as half an inch. These studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players of the time had many pairs with various stud lengths and this is probably the first time 2012 new adidas predator have evolved. Like football itself football shoes have gone through a lot of changes over the years. Before 1891 studs?blades or any other kind of sole were not allowed. After the 1891 changes?studs and blades became legal as long as they were made of leather and not as big as half an inch. These studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players of the time had many pairs with various stud lengths and this is probably the first time 2012 new adidas predator have evolved. The second evolution began in the mid-1950s and it is the most controversial. Football history noted that during the 1950's in Switzerland?Adidas who was Germany's boot supplier kitted the German team with the first ever screw-in-studs 2012 f50 adizero . However?Puma have counter claimed that they were supplying screw-in-studs as early as 1952. But whoever invented screw-in-studs the second evolution was the invention of the screw-in-studs boots. The first record of a pair of f50 adizero prime 2012 appears in 1526 in a list from King Henry VIII's Great Wardrobe which suggests he was not short of a few boots: \"45 velvet pairs and 1 leather pair for football\". His new 2012 adipowear predator were made by his personal shoemaker, Cornelius Johnson in 1525 at a cost of 4 shillings (about \uffe1100 in today's money). They were made of strong leather, ankle high and heavier than the normal shoe of the day\u2026 which position Henry played, we shall never know. Just like football itself 2012 new adidas predator went through a lot changes over the years. Until 1891, studs, blades or any other kind of projection weren't allowed. I consider this as the first time 2012 new football boots evolved. The second evolution came in the mid-1950s and it is also the most controversial. History says that during the 1954 in Switzerland, Adidas who was Germany's football boot supplier kitted the Germans with the first screw-in-studs messi 2012 boots ever seen. But recently Puma claimed that they were supplying screw in stud as early as 1952. Despite who invented screw in studs the point here is the that the second evolution was the invention of the screw in studs. Despite the screw-in debate another revolution was going on at roughly the same time in history. Between 1950 and 1960 new 2012 football shoes design took a huge step forward and boots really started to make an impact on the game. While in Northern Europe adidas football boots 2012 still had the ankle protection, main reason they are called \"boots\", South Americans created a more flexible and lighter boot without the ankle protection, a boot designed to increase control, improve kicking power and make players move faster and change direction quicker. After the 1891 changes?studs and blades became legal as long as they were made of leather and not as big as half an inch. These studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players of the time had many pairs with various stud lengths and this is probably the first time 2012 new adidas predator have evolved. The second evolution began in the mid-1950s and it is the most controversial. However?Puma have counter claimed that they were supplying screw-in-studs as early as 1952. But whoever invented screw-in-studs the second evolution was the invention of the screw-in-studs boots. After the 1891 changes?studs and blades became legal as long as they were made of leather and not as big as half an inch. These studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players of the time had many pairs with various stud lengths and this is probably the first time 2012 new adidas predator have evolved. Click here\nSubmitted by Giselle Goodman on Thu, 06/18/2009 - 08:00\nWelcome to the Sunrise Herald with Giselle Goodman, the place to go to get the news from overnight and onward...\n------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nSUNRISE: 4:59 a.m. SUNSET: 8:25 p.m.\nAt 9 a.m., it was 58 degrees in downtown Portland.\nRed\nsky in morning (sailor's warning). A crimson sunrise over Portland City\nHall at the start of this day tells us our lovely summer weather is\nfleeting.\nSunshine will be limited today, with clouds thickening as the day progresses. The most sun will be with us this morning.\nBut\nthere will be no sunrise pictures tomorrow. Rain develops tonight and\nwill be heavy by the morning.\u00a0 And, sorry to say, it's supposed to\nstick around for the entire weekend.\nTHE SUNRISE HERALD WEATHER WATCHERS REPORT:\nBill in Rockland says: A high grayness is spreading\nwest to east and the weak westerly breeze feels a little chilly. It's\nonly 48 degrees here at 5:30 and\nit seems cooler. I guess summer's gone again for a while.\nJim from Cape Elizabeth says:\nWe have milky skies this morning but it is dry (for the time being) and\n53 degrees at 6:15. The flags are barely rustling but not enough\u00a0 for\nanemometer to register a speed.\u00a0 The rain scheduled to creep in\novernight but only in the form of a few showers.\u00a0 The weekend is in\nsight.\u00a0 Weather permitting, the Sea Dogs are scheduled to have\nFireworks this evening, so get out and enjoy.\u00a0 See you tomorrow!\n------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nYou really can expect some traffic troubles now thanks to the Maine\nStreet reconstruction project. Longfellow Avenue went down to one lane\nyesterday. It will be fully closed Friday and Saturday.\nFrom today's Portland Press Herald dispatches: Public Works Director John Foster said the replacement storm drain\nline crossing Longfellow Avenue at Park Row and Maine Street must take\ninto consideration underground telephone, gas, water and sewer lines.\nAs a result, the work will be slow.\nHe advised motorists to find alternate routes and expect delays. The\nwork was scheduled to begin earlier this week but was delayed.\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nNot\nas lovely a day for ocean going today as it was yesterday. A southern\nwind blows 5 to 10 knots (not so bad) BUT gusts kick up as the day\nmoves on, hitting us with 20 knot blows and then coming from the\nsoutheast. Seas 2 to 3 feet.\nIN PORTLAND: High tide at 7:21 a.m. and 7:44 p.m. Low tide at 1:23 p.m.\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPORTLAND -- A man whose name goes hand-in-hand with some of Maine's\nfavorite pastimes will be honored tonight for being a champion of\npeople with disabilities.\nCromwell Center for Disabilities Awareness in Portland, will give its\n2009 \"Person of the Year\" award to Leslie \"Les\" Otten tonight during\nits annual gala and fundraising dinner.\nThe star-studded event,\nwhich will also be attended by Boston Red Sox President and CEO Larry\nLucchino, begins at the Marriott Sable Oaks in South Portland at 5:30\np.m.\nOtten (Portland Press Herald file photo at right) is the\nformer owner of Sunday River, and former CEO of American Skiing\nCompany, which owned Sugarloaf USA. He was once a minority owner of the\nBoston Red Sox, and has served as chairman of the Crowmwell Center's\nBoard of Directors for the past 5 years.\naccording to its mission statement, is an innovative leader in\ndisabilities awareness education in schools, for future educators, and\nin workplaces.\u00a0 The Center does not teach about particular\ndisabilities, engage in \"show and tell,\" or provide any direct services\nto persons with disabilities. The center seeks to change popular\nattitudes toward those with disabilities.\nThe event tonight is\nexpected to bring 350 people to the Marriott to honor Otten (and give\nhim some good-natured roasting) and to raise funds for the Cromwell\nCenter. Participants had to have registered in advance.\n---------------\n-- First-time home buyers may be getting some good news today, when the\ngovernor announces an initiative that will provide more than $5,000 in\nincentives for first-time buyers.\nGov. John E. Baldacci and\nMaineHousing Director Dale McCormick plan to make the announcement at a\n1:30 p.m. press conference today. The pair will make the announcement\nfrom the Greater Portland Board of REALTORS office, 2271 Congress\nStreet, Portland.\nRepresentatives from the Maine Association of\nREALTORS, the Maine Association of Community Banks and the Maine Credit\nUnion League also will be present.\n---------------\nTHE MORNING SENTINEL this morning provides this report:\nNORRIGEWOCK\n-- A 23-year-old Norridgewock man was killed late Tuesday after he\napparently failed to stop at the busy intersection of Route 139, the\nWaterville Road and U.S. Route 2 (Skowhegan Road), near the village\ncenter, police said Wednesday. The Somerset County Sheriff's Department\nsaid Randy Lake died in the accident. The four passengers in the second\nvehicle, including a 3-month-old\ninfant, were treated for injuries at a Skowhegan hospital. Gottardi\nsaid none of the injuries appeared life-threatening. To continue\nreading the full report on the crash, click here.\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nFYI:\nIf you gave or received one of these Blair robes as a gift, or own one at all, send it back. Pronto.\nThe\nU.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission is reannouncing the recall of\nthese chenille robes, sold by Blair from January 2003 through March\n2009.\nthe orignial recall, made in April 2009, Blair company has received\nreports of six (6) deaths due to the robes catching fire. Five of the\nwomen who died were cooking in the kitchen at the time the robe caught\nfire.\u00a0 Three of the victims were in their 80s.\nBlair, known for\nit's products that appeal to an older customer, announced the recall\nfor the robes after the company learned of three robes catching on\nfire, including one report of second-degree burns.\nThe recalled\nrobes have the following item numbers: 3093111, 3093112, 3093113,\n3093114, 3093115, and 3093116. The item number is identified on a label\nin the garment\u2019s neckline. CPSC said 162,000 robes have been sold in\nthe United States.\nIf you have one, stop using it immediately.\nIt can be returned to Blair for a refund. Call the Blair Recall Hotline\nat 1-877-392-7095 between 9 a.m. and 9 p.m. Monday through Saturday to\nfind out how.\nYup, that's right, folks. Today is the much-anticipated, long-awaited annual Maine Moose Permit Lottery.\nThe\nMaine Department of Inland Fisheries and Wildlife will be at the\nUniversity of Maine at Fort Kent for the ritual, which begins at 6 p.m.\nThis\nis the first year the lottery drawing has been held in the St. John\nValley. But it should not dampen the interest level. At last count,\n57,000 people had applied for the 3,105 permits to be awarded this\nevening.\nA lot of folks are hoping to bag the big one. Only those with a permit are allowed to hunt for moose in the fall.\nBut\nshould you not get lucky this time around, you can still have fun at\nthe lottery drawing event. Vendors and more than 40 exhibitors get\ntogether for the day, offering food and activities for the kids.Those\nactivities begin at 2 p.m.\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\nCopyright 2009 MaineToday Media, Inc. Like football itself football shoes have gone through a lot of changes over the years. Before 1891 studs?blades or any other kind of sole were not allowed. After the 1891 changes?studs and blades became legal as long as they were made of leather and not as big as half an inch. These studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players of the time had many pairs with various stud lengths and this is probably the first time 2012 new adidas predator have evolved. The second evolution began in the mid-1950s and it is the most controversial. Football history noted that during the 1950's in Switzerland?Adidas who was Germany's boot supplier kitted the German team with the first ever screw-in-studs 2012 f50 adizero . However?Puma have counter claimed that they were supplying screw-in-studs as early as 1952. But whoever invented screw-in-studs the second evolution was the invention of the screw-in-studs boots. The first record of a pair of f50 adizero prime 2012 appears in 1526 in a list from King Henry VIII's Great Wardrobe which suggests he was not short of a few boots: \"45 velvet pairs and 1 leather pair for football\". His new 2012 adipowear predator were made by his personal shoemaker, Cornelius Johnson in 1525 at a cost of 4 shillings (about \uffe1100 in today's money). They were made of strong leather, ankle high and heavier than the normal shoe of the day\u2026 which position Henry played, we shall never know. The earliest mercurial vapor 2012 had metal tacks hammered into them to increase ground grip and stability. With the foundation of the Football Association in 1863, rules were introduced that banned any kind of projection on the soles or heels of new 2012 football shoes but in 1891 the rules were revised to allow studs, so long as they were made of leather, were rounded, did not project more than half an inch and had their fastenings driven in. Believe it or not the use of adidas football boots 2012 dates back to Henry VIII of England. Her majesty ordered a pair from the Great Wardrobe in 1526, the royal shopping list stated: \"45 velvet pairs and 1 leather pair for football\". Just like football itself 2012 new adidas predator went through a lot changes over the years. Until 1891, studs, blades or any other kind of projection weren't allowed. After the 1891 revision, studs and bladders became \"legal\" as long as they were made of leather and weren't bigger than half an inch, this studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players at the time had several pairs with different length studs. I consider this as the first time 2012 new football boots evolved. The second evolution came in the mid-1950s and it is also the most controversial. History says that during the 1954 in Switzerland, Adidas who was Germany's football boot supplier kitted the Germans with the first screw-in-studs messi 2012 boots ever seen. But recently Puma claimed that they were supplying screw in stud as early as 1952. Despite who invented screw in studs the point here is the that the second evolution was the invention of the screw in studs. Despite the screw-in debate another revolution was going on at roughly the same time in history. Between 1950 and 1960 new 2012 football shoes design took a huge step forward and boots really started to make an impact on the game. While in Northern Europe adidas football boots 2012 still had the ankle protection, main reason they are called \"boots\", South Americans created a more flexible and lighter boot without the ankle protection, a boot designed to increase control, improve kicking power and make players move faster and change direction quicker. With greater contact areas, a series of power and swerve zones allowing players to create better swerves and more powerful strikes when hitting the so called \"sweet spots\". No wonder the Adidas Predator series are still in production these days. Johnston's creation was just the tip of the iceberg of what was coming. After the 1891 changes?studs and blades became legal as long as they were made of leather and not as big as half an inch. These studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players of the time had many pairs with various stud lengths and this is probably the first time 2012 new adidas predator have evolved. The second evolution began in the mid-1950s and it is the most controversial. Football history noted that during the 1950's in Switzerland?Adidas who was Germany's boot supplier kitted the German team with the first ever screw-in-studs 2012 f50 adizero . However?Puma have counter claimed that they were supplying screw-in-studs as early as 1952. But whoever invented screw-in-studs the second evolution was the invention of the screw-in-studs boots. After the 1891 changes?studs and blades became legal as long as they were made of leather and not as big as half an inch. These studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players of the time had many pairs with various stud lengths and this is probably the first time 2012 new adidas predator have evolved. The second evolution began in the mid-1950s and it is the most controversial. However?Puma have counter claimed that they were supplying screw-in-studs as early as 1952. But whoever invented screw-in-studs the second evolution was the invention of the screw-in-studs boots. After the 1891 changes?studs and blades became legal as long as they were made of leather and not as big as half an inch. These studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players of the time had many pairs with various stud lengths and this is probably the first time 2012 new adidas predator have evolved. Like football itself football shoes have gone through a lot of changes over the years. Before 1891 studs?blades or any other kind of sole were not allowed. After the 1891 changes?studs and blades became legal as long as they were made of leather and not as big as half an inch. These studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players of the time had many pairs with various stud lengths and this is probably the first time 2012 new adidas predator have evolved. The second evolution began in the mid-1950s and it is the most controversial. Football history noted that during the 1950's in Switzerland?Adidas who was Germany's boot supplier kitted the German team with the first ever screw-in-studs 2012 f50 adizero . However?Puma have counter claimed that they were supplying screw-in-studs as early as 1952. But whoever invented screw-in-studs the second evolution was the invention of the screw-in-studs boots. The first record of a pair of f50 adizero prime 2012 appears in 1526 in a list from King Henry VIII's Great Wardrobe which suggests he was not short of a few boots: \"45 velvet pairs and 1 leather pair for football\". His new 2012 adipowear predator were made by his personal shoemaker, Cornelius Johnson in 1525 at a cost of 4 shillings (about \uffe1100 in today's money). Just like football itself 2012 new adidas predator went through a lot changes over the years. Until 1891, studs, blades or any other kind of projection weren't allowed. I consider this as the first time 2012 new football boots evolved. The second evolution came in the mid-1950s and it is also the most controversial. History says that during the 1954 in Switzerland, Adidas who was Germany's football boot supplier kitted the Germans with the first screw-in-studs messi 2012 boots ever seen. But recently Puma claimed that they were supplying screw in stud as early as 1952. Despite who invented screw in studs the point here is the that the second evolution was the invention of the screw in studs. Despite the screw-in debate another revolution was going on at roughly the same time in history. Between 1950 and 1960 new 2012 football shoes design took a huge step forward and boots really started to make an impact on the game. While in Northern Europe adidas football boots 2012 still had the ankle protection, main reason they are called \"boots\", South Americans created a more flexible and lighter boot without the ankle protection, a boot designed to increase control, improve kicking power and make players move faster and change direction quicker. After the 1891 changes?studs and blades became legal as long as they were made of leather and not as big as half an inch. These studs and blades were originally hammered into the boots and professional players of the time had many pairs with various stud lengths and this is probably the first time 2012 new adidas predator have evolved. Last week, the state's secretaries of Health and Education named 40 middle schools as recipients of Active School grants.\nAn Aug. 20 news release provided the following details about the program, the grants and the extent of the childhood obesity problem in Pennsylvania:\nThe Active Schools Grant program implements evidence-based physical activity programs that meet the federal guidelines of moderate to vigorous daily physical activity\nEach school will receive a $5,000 grant from the Department of Health, through the federal Preventive Health and Health Services Block Grant. In addition, each school will receive a $10,000 grant from an organization in their region which has agreed to support the Active Schools program.\nBased on Body Mass Index (BMI) data submitted by the schools to the Department of Health, 16.07 percent of students in grades K-6 are overweight and another 16.67 percent are obese, making 32.74 percent of these Pennsylvania students either overweight or obese.\nParticipating partner organizations include the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center Health Plan, Blue Cross of Northeast Pennsylvania, and Capitol Blue Cross.\n"}, {"score": 317.09286, "uuid": "7cc4e3f2-e4b2-57b7-9569-ca7eff14f635", "index": "cw12", "trec_id": "clueweb12-1410wb-21-01717", "target_hostname": "cliniclegal.org", "target_uri": "http://cliniclegal.org/blog/1107/dream-act-primer-debate-destaca-beneficios", "page_rank": 1.171648e-09, "spam_rank": 95, "title": "DREAM Act: Primer debate destaca beneficios | CLINIC", "snippet": "<em>I</em> bought some Cheap Louis Vuitton Bags last year from Louis Vuitton Outlet italy,but <em>i</em> <em>am</em> very disappointed ,becasue the quality of some bags <em>are</em> not very good. Todos ellos sue\u00f1an con una carrera que les permita realizarse y contribuir al progreso de los EE.UU., pero han descubierto que nuestras leyes migratorias les niegan aquel sue\u00f1o. Como muchos de ellos, Ola hizo el descubrimiento con sus manos esposadas durante horas a una silla en una oficina del DHS.\nAlbania, donde Ola naci\u00f3, China, Guatemala, M\u00e9xico, Korea, Nigeria ... todos estos lugares tiene algo en com\u00fan; ninguno representa para estos chicos lo que este pa\u00eds representa: Su \u00fanico y verdadero hogar. Por esta y otras razones, Ola y todos los que se identifican con su calvario celebraron la hist\u00f3rica decisi\u00f3n del Senado de iniciar el debate sobre el Dream Act.\nEL proyecto de ley faculta a inmigrantes que se hayan criado en EE.UU. puedan optar a la residencia legal y eventualmente acceder a la ciudadan\u00eda siempre y cuando estudien en la universidad o sirvan en las Fuerzas Armadas.\nPese a la audiencia, no hay garant\u00edas que esta ley sea promulgada. Pero el tema adquiri\u00f3 suficiente relevancia como para incluirlo en la agenda legislativa. El debate propici\u00f3 una oportunidad para crear conciencia sobre la necesidad de legislar para que estos j\u00f3venes inmigrantes indocumentados puedan legalizar su estatus migratorio.\nEn el debate participaron senadores dem\u00f3cratas y funcionarios de la administraci\u00f3n Obama. Todos declararon que esta ley permitir\u00eda a la justicia dedicarse a perseguir a immigrantes que representan una amenaza en lugar de hostigar a j\u00f3venes cuyo talento acad\u00e9mico representa un aporte para la econom\u00eda.\u00a0 La medida permitir\u00eda aumentar el PGB en casi US$3.6 billones gracias al consumo y las contribuciones fiscales de este grupo etario.\u00a0 Representantes del Pent\u00e1gono, por otra parte, est\u00e1n convencidos que la ley beneficiar\u00e1 a las FF.AA. Los republicanos, sin embargo, cuestionan la presunta eficacia de esta ley y su capacidad para producir tal bonanza.\nM\u00e1s all\u00e1 de la pol\u00edtica o la econom\u00eda, conviene meditar las razones que los cat\u00f3licos esgrimimos para apoyar el Dream Act.\nLa Iglesia reconoce el derecho soberano de todas las naciones a resguardar sus fronteras. Sin embargo, se\u00f1ala que todos los seres humanos tienen derecho a emigrar en busca de trabajo y oportunidades y a ser reconocidos como miembros de la familia humana. Jes\u00fas y su Familia, nos recuerda la Iglesia, vivieron el exilio como refugiados.\nLa doctrina social de la Iglesia conmemora la vida del Cristo errante que predic\u00f3 de un lugar a otro sin residencia fija. Y de acuerdo a esa experiencia, exige que demos al forastero el mismo trato hospitalario, generoso y digno que Cristo recibi\u00f3 cuando fue forastero. En su mensaje para la Jornada Mundial del Migrante de 1995, el Papa Juan Pablo II y los obispos de EE.UU. y M\u00e9xico nos entregaron un mensaje. Un legado universal pensado en el futuro, para este pa\u00eds y para todo el mundo:\n\"En la Iglesia nadie es extranjero, y la Iglesia no es extranjera para ning\u00fan hombre y en ning\u00fan lugar. Como sacramento de unidad y por tanto, como signo y fuerza de agregaci\u00f3n de todo el g\u00e9nero humano, la Iglesia es el lugar donde tambi\u00e9n los emigrantes indocumentados son reconocidos y acogidos como hermanos\".\nTags:\n"}, {"score": 316.04422, "uuid": "13b961db-a2ef-5cd5-a133-99b769263acd", "index": "cw12", "trec_id": "clueweb12-0706wb-49-16750", "target_hostname": "www.wildlifealliance.org", "target_uri": "http://www.wildlifealliance.org/blog/2011/4/25/a-school-visit-with-the-kouprey-express.html", "page_rank": 1.1773421e-09, "spam_rank": 87, "title": "A school visit with the Kouprey Express - Field Blog - Wildlife", "snippet": "Oh very well, <em>I</em> will be far more careful in <em>which</em> <em>I</em> leave my shoes from now on. of how <em>to</em> drive a car! She was always driven around by either her mum <em>or</em> her boyfriend.", "explanation": null, "document": "A school visit with the Kouprey\u00a0Express\nMonday, April 25, 2011 at 1:32PM\nHave you ever wondered what goes on when our Kouprey Express mobile environmental education unit visits a school?\nThe March school visits to Angkor Phnom Klong and Veal primary schools in the Cardamom Mountains are a typical example:\nTeacher Capacity Building\nFor three days, the Kouprey Express staff and educators conducted intensive full-day workshops with ten teachers from Angkor Phnom Klong and Veal primary schools in Cambodia\u2019s Koh Kong Province. The team delivered modules on weather, water resources, waste and sanitation, and energy and climate. The final day of workshops featured modules on biodiversity conservation and sustainable livelihoods. After these sessions, the teachers showed greater understanding of each module, and had clear instructions about how to integrate these environment concepts into their core classroom lessons and activities to increase awareness of their students of environmental issues and what the students can do to help protect their natural resources and have a positive impact on their environment.\nStudent Education\nWhile developing teacher capacity is critical for the long-term success of our education initiatives, the core of the Kouprey Express remains classroom education with underserved village schools in protected areas. In rural Cambodia, access to education is only sporadic. Many students will attend school only until they can work full-time, and others will attend classes but have to work in agriculture or fishing during the busy part of the year.\nAt Angkor Phnom Klong and Veal primary schools, the Kouprey Express provided lessons for 290 students from Grades 4 through 6,\u00a0using a flipchart-based curriculum that can easily be transferred from one school to another, maintaining a consistent lesson plan that was adapted in partnership with the environmental education NGO Live & Learn. Each school is supplied with a flipchart, complete with lesson plans, activities, and ideas that the teachers can use over and over again.\nThe Kouprey Express spent most of the week working with the teachers and students at Angkor Phnom Klong and Veal primary schools. Highlights of the visit included an interactive demonstration of the Web of Life game, which highlights the interconnectivity of forests, wildlife, and humans.\nThis game is played by the whole class either inside or outside the classroom, by giving pictures and a string to all students and asking students to stand as circle. For example, if a student is given a picture of the Sun, she will will need to explain why she is important and what role she plays, for example, \u201cI am the sun so I will spread my light to feed the trees,\u201d and then the Sun gives the string to the student holding the picture of a tree. After that the Tree will state his importance, for example, \u201cI am a Tree and I need water for my life,\u201d so the Tree passes the string to the student with the Water card, and so on. When the game finishes the strings from one student to another will look like a spider web. We then explain to students how important and interconnected the web of life is, and how no element can be removed from the ecosystem without affecting the wellbeing of the other components.\nAfter each Kouprey Express visit, students and teachers are quizzed on their knowledge about environmental principles. The testing illustrates that students understand more clearly such concepts as wildlife protection, the meaning of extinction, and the importance of forests. In particular, students really enjoyed playing environmentally-themed games, such as the Web of Life game. After the school visit, many students also said they felt it is easier to spread environmental concepts and awareness to their friends and family, and share their knowledge with other members of the community.\nEach visit to a school is a lengthy process - not simply the week or more spent at each site, but extensive preparation and curriculum development. Each set of trainings with teachers, and classroom- and field-based education with students is usually complemented with a Community Night Show (CNS) that reaches the broader community of nearby villages and settlements. In each CNS, the Kouprey Express team uses interactive games, videos, puppet shows, and music to illustrate environmental principles to the broader community - and thousands may attend each night, drawn in by the opportunity to also participate in karaoke and watch popular movies!\n"}], [{"score": 315.88147, "uuid": "63577745-10bd-502f-a75f-d3af3ea47bfe", "index": "cw12", "trec_id": "clueweb12-0911wb-55-10913", "target_hostname": "northwestguide.com", "target_uri": "http://northwestguide.com/attraction/yakima-park-stockade-group", "page_rank": 1.178268e-09, "spam_rank": 69, "title": "Yakima Park Stockade Group | Northwest Guide", "snippet": "weren&#x27;t <em>planning</em> <em>to</em> <em>buy</em>.", "explanation": null, "document": ""}, {"score": 313.19385, "uuid": "c06ca67c-3ced-5524-8916-64c87fe55c28", "index": "cw12", "trec_id": "clueweb12-0717wb-47-06092", "target_hostname": "ibma.org", "target_uri": "http://ibma.org/node/135", "page_rank": 1.2866521e-09, "spam_rank": 81, "title": "Local 1000 Union Membership Offers Benefits <em>to</em> Bluegrass Musicians | International", "snippet": "Another great example of innovation, <em>I</em> <em>am</em> glad <em>to</em> find it. There <em>are</em> so many developers working on this segment but this is one of the best innovative idea ever. Thanks for sharing it here.", "explanation": null, "document": "Local 1000 Union Membership Offers Benefits to Bluegrass Musicians\nby John McCutcheon\nWhen IBMA board member Tim Stafford asked me to speak to the Artist and Composers Branch at the organization\u2019s annual conference I was all too happy to oblige.\u00a0 I started my professional career in the old-time music world, frequently played bluegrass festivals and, more than anything, recognized that the gains we folk musicians had won via unionization could and should be naturally shared with our fellow performers in the bluegrass field.\nLocal 1000 was chartered about a dozen years ago within the American Federation of Musicians (AFM), the world\u2019s largest entertainment union.\u00a0 What is unique about Local 1000 is that it is the only non-geographic local in the AFM.\u00a0 Just as unusual is the fact that it was created to solely serve the needs of those of us who travel for the large part of their work.\u00a0 Finally, the benefits of union membership could be fully enjoyed by people who were not symphony players, recording studio musicians, pit bands or lounge acts.\u00a0 Finally, those of us who played one-night stands, clubs, festivals,\u00a0community events, etc. could access the AFM\u2019s amazing pension plan, get basic health care, find affordable and workable instrument insurance, and have someone to stand up for us not only after trouble happens,\u00a0 but also be an advocate for policies that will help prevent that trouble in the first place.\nTim\u2019s initial interest was in health care.\u00a0 Bluegrass musicians are not alone in worrying about being uninsured.\u00a0 Tens of millions of our fellow Americans are in the same boat.\u00a0 People without health insurance live sicker and die younger.\u00a0 They neglect routine checkups and roll the dice every day of their lives that misfortune will not ruin them and their loved ones.\u00a0 We at Local 1000 offer a very basic health plan that, while far from perfect, gives some protection to the traveling musician.\u00a0 We\u2019ve created a committee that is looking into additional options for people like us that can be offered, albeit at higher costs, to interested members.\u00a0 A full report will be presented in the next six months.\nOne of the most immediately accessible benefits of Local membership is the AFM Pension Plan.\u00a0 Thanks to the joint experimentation of NYC Local 802 and Local 1000, there is now a Federation-wise contract form, known as the LS-1, that allows a pension contribution on every gig a member performs.\u00a0 Many of our members have incorporated and sign collective bargaining agreements with the Local to further streamline the paperwork.\u00a0 Add up even a few years of contributions, and it can mean a pension of hundreds (or thousands) of dollars per month when a musician \u201cretires\u201d at age 65.\u00a0 It doesn\u2019t prevent a performer from gigging further and also allows private retirement options via the Roth IRA.\nBeyond the pension and health care, many musicians are finally getting real protection for their instruments and equipment via the Union\u2019s equipment insurance.\u00a0 It covers any instruments and equipment involved in our work (PA\u2019s, recording equipment, office equipment, computers, etc.) for any loss, theft or damage anytime, anywhere.\u00a0 Most importantly it covers this equipment at replacement value and is extremely affordable.\nBesides these obvious \u201cpocketbook\u201d issues (there are many more: visit www.local1000.com ), there are issues of advocacy and solidarity.\u00a0 Members of IBMA know that there are many things that organizations can accomplish that individuals simply cannot or will not tackle.\u00a0 Like the North American Folk Music and Dance Alliance, IBMA is a conglomerate of every facet of its musical field: players, yes, but also promoters, festivals, publications, equipment manufacturers, record companies and more.\u00a0 Local 1000 is the only group within IBMA or the Folk Alliance whose sole charge is the welfare of musicians.\u00a0 Like any democratic organization, it is only as strong as its membership.\u00a0 We have made great strides pushing for changes in the folk music world that are now a normal\u00a0part of practice in clubs, concert halls and festivals.\u00a0 This was done because musicians realized that making our lives more secure made our folk music community more secure.\u00a0 We believe the same is true in the bluegrass world.\nIt was wonderful seeing so many old friends at IBMA.\u00a0 What was even more exciting was seeing how many bluegrass musicians felt that the time was right to rethink what the AFM is and is not.\u00a0 Now with a Local that was chartered by and for traveling musicians and run by traveling musicians, many old road warriors are coming back home to the AFM.\u00a0 It\u2019s not your father\u2019s union.\u00a0 It\u2019s ours and it\u2019s time to make it everything we\u2019ve always dreamed it might be.\nLocal 1000 will be a regular and visible participant in IBMA from now on.\u00a0 We welcome the participation of every bluegrass musician.\u00a0 We welcome the kind of ideas that have fueled some of our most far-fetched accomplishments.\u00a0 And, most of all, we want to welcome all our fellow performers into a future that provides greater dignity and security to our field.\u00a0 Thanks for the hospitality and we\u2019ll see you next year in Nashville.\u00a0 In the meantime, I can be reached at president@afm1000.com .\nInfo:\nAmerican Federation of Musicians of the United States and Canada\nOffice of the President\nLog in or register to post comments\n70 reacties\nThe Association (IBMA), which serves as the trade association for the bluegrass music industry. These Chum are intercepted inrout to rivers in lower British Columbia and Washington state area. Their skin is bright as they are harvested before full maturity, producing the best of Canada\u2019s Keta run. Act quickly because there will only be two 48-hour openings. The Strait will open on Oct. 4th for two days, and Oct. 18th for two days.\nChums will also be available in the Puget Sound beginning Oct. 7th. Traditionally, the runs do not kick into gear until Oct. 15th. The best Chums are caught in October, but will be available up to Thanksgiving.\nCoho are currently being caught in moderate numbers in Bellingham Bay in the Puget Sound. These are competitively priced fish and are looking great.
