It makes my reading even more interesting and pleasant! - http://www.kisslouboutin.com/\nPosted by Discount Christian Louboutin Shoes at December 30, 2011, 8:24 pm\nFar water does not put out near fire.\nPosted by womens nike heels at January 5, 2012, 3:39 pm\nGood watch prevents misfortune.\n"}, {"score": 302.07852, "uuid": "d318a146-8ec9-5153-b03a-1aa01e68c00c", "index": "cw12", "trec_id": "clueweb12-1114wb-12-27399", "target_hostname": "ncf.colorado.edu", "target_uri": "http://ncf.colorado.edu/?p=news&sub=tinytech&id=59", "page_rank": 1.175978e-09, "spam_rank": 76, "title": "Nanomaterials Characterization Facility | Bacteria in Space: Behavior", "snippet": "There is a wide range of Suzuki Motorcycle Parts available from <em>which</em> you can select any that you need. Some time you <em>are</em> in a confusion and don\u2019t know <em>which</em> way <em>to</em> go rather <em>to</em> <em>buy</em> a new motorbike part <em>or</em> if <em>buy</em> a used bike part then from where <em>to</em> <em>buy</em> it?", "explanation": null, "document": "By Dan Ray\nPublished 8/1/2008\nSpace flight does a lot more than just cause astronauts to float. In fact, the effects of zero gravity are felt on the microscopic scale as well \u2013 between individual cells or even molecules \u2013 and in ways that are not yet fully understood.\nAt the University of Colorado-Boulder , Professor of Aerospace Engineering Sciences David Klaus has been conducting research that may help biologists model one of the most fundamental \u2013 but imperfectly understood \u2013communication mechanisms between cells: extracellular molecular transport .\nThis graph shows the very basic stages of growth that most bacterial cultures undergo, where L represents the log of the bacterial population and T represents time. Basically, A is the period of time at which bacteria remain in their lag phase, prior to exponential doubling -- portion B of the graph. In space, A is significantly shorter, causing the bacterial population to reach higher numbers sooner than here on Earth.\n\u201cGenerally speaking, bacteria tend to grow better in space,\u201d Klaus said. \u201cThe first and most fundamental bacterial response to spaceflight is a shortened lag phase .\u201d\nLag phase is the term used to describe the amount of time a bacterial culture, or sample, remains at a relatively constant number of cells following inoculation , while adapting to the surrounding environmental conditions, according to Klaus.\nEssentially, when bacteria are first introduced into a new growth medium\u2013 such as a human\u2019s bloodstream \u2013 the cells tend to spend a certain amount of time simply distributing themselves or spreading out into new areas, prior to dividing and increasing their numbers exponentially . This is true of most cellular organisms.\nIn space, on the other hand, where there is no gravity , cells behave differently. The adaptive lag stage of bacterial growth is significantly reduced, typically resulting in much higher numbers of bacterial cells being produced in a shorter amount of time than we would otherwise see on Earth.\nBiologists speculate that while bacterial cells are in this holding pattern prior to their growth phase, the cells are releasing certain molecular compounds. It is the relative abundance of these compounds that indicates to nearby cells when it is time to begin dividing.\nSo, if the environment surrounding a cell does not contain sufficient signaling compounds from other cells, then it does not yet begin to divide and may, in fact, even die before dividing. And later, after a certain amount of time, when the culture has reached a mature stage in its development, another chemical signal arrives, announcing that it is time to stop doubling.\nOne of the compact module systems that Klaus and his students have built to conduct their bacterial research onboard spacecrafts. These systems must be small and reliable to both fit in the cramped area of a spacecraft and to minimize the chances of failure so far from home.\n\u201cThis is essentially how bacteria communicate with each other,\u201d Klaus said.\nIt is by sending these chemical signals that bacterial cells communicate their presence to other nearby cells. The cells release specific molecules at certain stages in their life cycle. This mass signaling and coordinated behavior of bacterial cells is known as quorum sensing .\nDepending on the type of bacteria, the different chemical signals released can trigger a wide variety of responses across many billions of cells \u2013 working almost simultaneously in some cases.\nAlthough there can be many responses to these chemical signals among different types of bacteria, one behavior has been observed almost universally when bacteria are put in a zero-G environment: increased growth caused by a shortened lag phase.\n\u201cResearch groups around the world have reported this same basic result in many flight experiments,\u201d Klaus said.\nThe difference between how bacteria grow in space and how they grow on Earth is likely to be driven by the way these chemical signals are transported between cells, he said.\n\u201cSecreted substances migrate to other cells through fluid transport mechanisms,\u201d Klaus said.\nClearly, since the signals between cells are being received at different points in a culture\u2019s lifecycle, this means that the way the chemical signals are moving through the fluid between cells \u2013 which is mainly water, in this case \u2013 is different without gravity.\nAstronaut Dan Bursch operating BioServe\u2019s Payload containing the microbial drug production experiment onboard the International Space Station\nNormally, here on Earth, the signaling chemicals used by cells to talk to each other travel via two physical processes: diffusion and convection .\nDiffusion and convection work simultaneously to spread molecules throughout the water these bacterial cells are living in.\nDiffusion is basically the same phenomenon you might experience daily, if someone is cooking in your kitchen. If macaroni and cheese is cooking in your kitchen, as you sit in your living room, it will take a few minutes for the smell of the food to reach your nose. But if you were closer to the food, then you would smell it much sooner.\nThis effect is driven simply by the individual macaroni and cheese molecules traveling through the air, bumping into each other and other air particles, and, through time, spreading from an area of high concentration \u2013 your kitchen \u2013 to an area of low concentration \u2013 your living room.\nThis is one of the ways that bacterial cells allow signals to travel between them. The molecules they release travel from the high concentrated area immediately around their cell walls, to low concentrated areas nearby other cells, simply through molecular collisions occurring on the scale of just a few hundred nanometers . Accordingly, these cells can gauge the amount of molecules from other cells around them to determine how many other cells are in the local area.\nOf course, in the real world, diffusion is not the only way these molecules move. Convection accounts for a large part of this transport system too.\nConvection is the name given to the motion of various molecules in a fluid arising due to differences in their mass densities. In our atmosphere \u2013 which is a fluid \u2013 convection is largely caused by density differences created by heat.\nWhen the sun\u2019s light strikes the ground, this only heats up a few meager inches of the air immediately above the ground, through conduction . If conduction were the only force spreading the heat of the sun around the planet, then the Earth would be a vastly colder place than it is.\nFortunately, the small layer of heated air above the ground is pushed up higher into the atmosphere by colder, heavier air rushing in underneath it. Ultimately, hot air is more buoyant than more dense cold air. And this property results in a gravity-driven convective force that churns the air of our atmosphere and spreads warm air molecules more efficiently than might otherwise occur.\nBetween cells, Klaus suspects that differences are created in fluid densities. Some molecules are big and heavy \u2013 causing them to sink toward the bottom of a solution \u2013 while others are small and light \u2013 causing them to float toward the top. This also causes convection \u2013 like that in our atmosphere \u2013 but on a microscopic scale.\nHowever, when there is no gravity, the relative buoyancy of these molecules is unimportant. Since when gravity is gone, there is no force pulling heavy molecules down and pushing lighter molecules up. There is no convection.\nAs a result, many chemical signals between bacterial cells may not be distributed as quickly or efficiently in space than they are on Earth. The lack of gravity distorts the chemical signal.\nKlaus suspects that when gravity is removed from the system, one of the two major ways that molecules move through water is effectively deleted. So, when bacterial cells are sitting in their lag phase in outer space, they are receiving signals about how many other cells are around them only through diffusion, so the overall transport process is slowed. This is related to the suspected reason why they begin their growth phase earlier.\nHowever, it is not yet known precisely what molecules trigger the end of lag phase and signal the bacteria to divide, Klaus said.\n\u201cWhat is being transported of significance and consequence is what we\u2019re wondering,\u201d he said. \u201cThe holy grail of this whole thing is to be able to apply the beneficial responses observed in space to manipulate a process on Earth.\u201d\nUnderstanding how to trigger a shortened lag phase would be of benefit to bioprocessing production on Earth, Klaus said.\n\u201cThe question is what molecules are causing this,\u201d he said. \u201cIf we could add the right molecules into the mix at the right time we could potentially shorten the lag phase and allow the desired production to begin sooner, which could be a significant cost saving factor.\u201d\nOverall, the task is to reverse-engineer the physical process of this observed effect, so that the chemicals involved can be indentified, Klaus said.\n\u201cWe need to use space to better understand this transition,\u201d he said.\n\u201cHistorically, it has been biologists that have looked at this research area,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019ve been one of the few engineers straddling this divide with some new ideas. It makes a good multidisciplinary approach.\u201d\nOne of Klaus\u2019 future plans involves methods for observing the transport of these tiny signaling molecules directly on the scale of just a few nanometers.\n\u201cSo far, that has eluded us,\u201d he said.\nRelated Sites\n"}]]}
